Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2016 06:58PM Lou10 wrote: Sorry you are feeling poorly and worried. Infections can cause lumps, swelling, warmth, redness, etc.; if they become systemic, they can make you feel sick. Keep an eye on your temperature. If things get worse before your appointment, go to Emergency. I had a nasty breast infection and you don't want to ignore potential infections. You don't sound like a hypochondriac. Even if you weren't having the warmth, it would make sense to get any breast changes checked out. Take care of yourself.
Posts.Title: Concerned but probably overreacting KLunsure Lou10

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2012 08:21PM Lou10 wrote: Not sure where you live, but Lion's Gate Hospital is good for breast MRIs ... newer equipment and imaging software (I've gone there for two post-tx MRIs). Another woman mentioned having her biopsies there.  Not all radiology departments provide BIRADs ratings. None of my mammogram reports, nor an ultrasound report, prior to being diagnosed had BIRADS ratings. I've been to different hospitals since and their reports have provided BIRADS ratings. Hang in there. Hope it'll turn out to be B9.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2011 09:22AM Lou10 wrote: Great topic. Sure can relate. I decided to TRY to have a lower stress weekend and not obsess about cancer. Yesterday I returned a call from an old friend who lives far away from me, and I started off by saying I didn't want to talk about anything negative. Initially I had nothing to say ... we were talking about the weather!! Then cancer entered the conversation as she asked about my cat (even my cat has cancer!) and I asked about her dog (cancer!) So I thought, forget it, and gave her an update on my cancer treatments and stuff. Today I woke up worrying about money and was actually GLAD because my first thought wasn't about cancer (although of course it's the cancer that has put me in this financial mess).

Posts.Content: May 4, 2014 01:41PM Lou10 wrote: My biopsy was going to be scheduled for a week after my ultrasound but I had it done the same day because there was a cancellation and I was from out of town. Also I was at a Rapid Access Breast Clinic, which is supposed to fast track diagnosis. I got the results of the biopsy about a week later (my GP called me). Wouldn't hurt to call and make sure the hospital received the requisition. I've done that for MRIs before and then I was given a sense of how long the wait might be. Hope you get good news whenever you get it done.

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2012 12:46PM Lou10 wrote: Forgot to mention. There's a book called "The Pink Ribbon Diet" (2010) by Mary Flynn, RD, and Nancy Verde Barr that recognizes the weight gain from breast cancer treatment (which is validating!) and provides a plan for weight loss through healthy eating, along with 150 or so recipes. The subtitle is "A Revolutionary New Weight Loss Plan to Lower Your Breast Cancer Risk" but it's not just for people at risk. It's also for people who have gained weight through treatment for breast cancer.

I don't think any of us should beat ourselves up for weight gain ... it's a side effect of the cancer and treatment that may take some time to recover from.

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2012 10:32AM Lou10 wrote: ali68 - My onc told me to keep a log of my symptoms during my 4-5 week "trial separation" from Tamoxifen, to determine how much effect it had been having. When I saw my onc again, we decided I should switch to an aromatase inhibitor based on the improvement in my symptoms. I had been worried about going off hormonal therapy for that period of time as I am ER+++/PR+++. My onc said it wouldn't affect my risk since hormonal therapy is given for such a long time. Taking the break had to be looked at in that context. I'm now on escitalopram (lexapro) for depression ... it's a very close cousin to citalopram (celexa), which I had been on, but possibly helps more with anxiety as well.
Posts.Title: I have gone mad ali68 thefuzzylemon

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2012 11:03AM Lou10 wrote: P.S. Maybe Tamoxifen isn't the culprit in your case, but you won't know unless you go off it. And my onc said the break has to be about a month for it to get out of your system. I wish I had communicated how badly I was feeling sooner, like at 2 months on Tamoxifen instead of waiting for my next 6-month appointment after that ... maybe I'd have moved on with my life by now. Instead I lost more time and who needs that?!

Posts.Title: MRI inconclusive. Ultrasound friday. Help. Jrsully reflect

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2012 04:45PM Lou10 wrote: Sorry to butt in on this forum as I'm not stage III, but the topic jumped out at me. ali68, I was where you are at about the same time (except the marriage bit as I'm single :)) Thefuzzylemon, it continued for many months after active treatment 'though maybe not quite as intensely as initially. And I was on an anti-depressant (was on one before BC and still am).  I still get very angry sometimes, and my triggers seem to be 1) people who don't "get it" and 2) frustration over things I can't do or mess up, and how long it is taking to recover. However, my mood (and other SEs, including sleep) improved when I had a trial separation from Tamoxifen for 4-5 weeks. I'm now on an AI instead, Femara, and feel more like myself (whatever that now is ) ... I've only been on it about a month, so I hope that lasts. If you aren't on an anti-depressant, you may want to try one. I switched mine this year to one which is better for both depression and anxiety. Also Tamoxifen may be wreaking havoc with your mood.

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 08:56PM Lou10 wrote: Sorry no great diet tips but a lot of empathy! My weight came off gradually after I finished chemo, even while on tamoxifen. Then I went on an aromatase inhibitor and 2/3 of my weight is back. I can totally relate to the frustration. Not only do I look overweight again (yes, the preggers look), I was in the pre-diabetes range after chemo and I'm worried that with the weight coming back, I may be diabetic when I'm next tested.
Posts.Title: Will I ever quit gaining weight??? melmcbee LtotheK

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2012 06:34AM - edited Sep 27, 2012 06:35AM by Lou10 I got a pixie cut before chemo began. I had long hair and hacked a lot of it off one night after coming back from seeing my oncologist, then luckily got an appointment the next day to have it cut properly. When my hair was really falling out, I trimmed it with a razor and then shaved it (very carefully as I was concerned about nicks, having had some bad infections). I certainly didn't have fun doing it and I never went "topless" outside, but it helped me to take a bit of control over how my hair came out. Hope it's not too tough for you.

Posts.Title: What to ask ? Mother4Life Lou10

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2012 12:28PM Lou10 wrote: Hi all, A close friend of mine was recently diagnosed with a second breast cancer, 4 years after DCIS with microinvasion and ITCs in her sentinel node. This time it's stage III, I think IIIa. She had a UMX and discovered that the supposed 1.5 cm tumour of IDC in her breast was in fact two huge masses -- IDC and DCIS -- that basically took up her entire breast. She's now planning to have the other breast removed, since these large tumours were not discovered despite regular surveillance with mammo, U/S, AND MRI. She's struggling with whether she should have the other breast removed now, before starting chemo, rather than waiting until her active treatments are completed. She's very concerned that her remaining breast also has cancer. Since the cancer has spread to her lymph nodes, she'll be having a couple of scans for distant mets prior to starting chemo. If you were in her shoes, would you wait for the scan results before deciding whether, or when, to have another UMX? In other words, if she is found to have MBC, would it still make sense to have a prophylactic MX? Or what if cancer were known to be in her remaining breast? Do you stil treat the breast separately when you have MBC?  Many thanks for your help!
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2012 12:51PM Lou10 wrote: Karen - If Neupogen shots aren't covered by your provincial plan (i.e., with a request for special authorization from your doctor), then your doctor/oncologist may apply on your behalf to the Victory Program, which can cover the costs.  Also check out the Thrive Alive foundation: www.thrivealive.ca/ They can help cover various things for people with cancer who have low incomes, including medications not covered by provincial plans. There may be other side effect medications not covered by your provincial plan.  Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2012 06:05AM Lou10 wrote: Mine felt completely different. It just felt like a hardened area in my breast ... no roundness, hard to find where the edges were ... wasn't what I expected a "lump" to feel like. Sure hope yours is a cyst. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Worried 27 year old mother! What did your lump feel like? AJS715 Letlet

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2016 11:13AM Lou10 wrote: Ask for an ultrasound of your extra breast tissue and left breast because of the changes and because your extra breast tissue should be screened along with your breasts. It can develop malignancies too. I saw my (then) doctor about the increase in the size of my breast about two years before I was diagnosed, and raised the issue again a year before. He said it was nothing to worry about and my mammograms found nothing. He didn't mention that the mammograms were essentially useless for me because of my extremely dense breasts, and in those days I didn't get copies of my records.

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2012 01:11PM Lou10 wrote: A friend of mine just had an axillary node biopsy but it was a fine needle aspiration, not a core biopsy. While a fine needle aspiration is easier, if it is either of those types of biopsies, it shouldn't be a big deal. You may already have had one or both types when you had the breast biopsies. I've only had core biopsies but others have told me that a fine needle aspiration doesn't even require numbing with local anesthetic.

It also picked up a third mass but the radiologist said in the MRI report that it didn't look malignant. I had to have the third area biopsied later, and the radiologist was right about it not being malignant. Hope yours turns out fine.
Posts.Title: going to Breast Oncologist Monday momma4boys momma4boys

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 07:34AM Lou10 wrote: I had two lumps, IDC of 2.5 cm, and a smaller lump that turned out to be DCIS. I had extremely dense breasts and it was the pre-surgery MRI that found the second lump. The MRI results came back so near to my surgery date there was no time to do a biopsy of the second lump. Because the two lumps were in the same area, the surgeon said she felt she could get them both via lumpectomy and didn't recommend changing the surgery to an MX. I had faith in her and probably would have gone with whatever she suggested. Fortunately, she got clear margins. If I had known more about my risk I might have considered MX, but I didn't. I made the decision that felt right to me at the time and I don't regret it. Wish you and your wife the best.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed now MRI finds a 2nd Lump jfelice Camillia

Posts.Content: Lou10 wrote: I'll be starting FEC-D shortly and would love to hear about others' experiences. I'm trying to decide whether to have it administered in the small town where I live, or to travel by ferry to have it in the city where my oncologist is. I'd prefer to have my oncologist directly oversee my treatment, but he said it would be a very long day and I'd need someone with me to drive me home. He sees his out-of-town patients in the morning and they go for their treatment in the afternoon (add to that the travel time). When I asked about driving, he said even if I was feeling up to it, I could have an allergic reaction to the chemo and need a high dose of benadryl, preventing me from driving. I wondered about staying overnight in the city, but that would mean boarding my dog and cat, which I really don't want to do. Even if I could find suitable pet-friendly accommodation in the city, that would mean hauling all their stuff. Also, I've heard from others that they want to be in their own bed after chemo. Thanks.  Diagnosis: 12/15/2010, IDC (plus DCIS & ILC), 2.5cm IDC, Stage IIb or III (unknown -- radiation to lymph nodes instead of ALND surgery), Grade 2, 2/2 nodes (sentinel and intramammary fully involved with extracapsular extension), ER+++/PR+++, HER2- Surgery 1/25/2011 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Chemotherapy 4/13/2011 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Ellence (epirubicin), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 9/14/2011 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 11/7/2011 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Hormonal Therapy 8/22/2012 Femara (letrozole) Hormonal Therapy 7/10/2013 Aromasin (exemestane) Hormonal Therapy 7/12/2014 Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: FEC-D Experiences Lou10 Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2012 05:58PM Lou10 wrote: Intramammary lymph nodes are found in about 5% of mammograms, according to one source. An intramammary lymph node may appear or enlarge in response to (benign) inflammatory conditions of the skin; they also may be associated with cancer. The characteristics of the node usually gives some indication of whether it is suspicious for malignancy. Perhaps in your last mammogram it didn't look suspcious, but they want to follow it to make sure it doesn't become suspicious. When you have your follow-up mammogram, you may want to ask if other imaging is recommended because of your dense breast tissue (even if the node is no longer an issue). Hope all turns out fine.
Posts.Title: Intramammary lymph node concern ? fintouch Lou10

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2012 08:51PM Lou10 wrote: Bob, so sorry your wife and you are going through this. I had the choice of two surgeons, one of whom could do the surgery more quickly. However, a nurse at the clinic pulled me aside and told me the surgeon with the longer wait was extremely experienced. My gut told me to go with the surgeon with more expertise, even though I knew little about either of them. Turned out to be a good choice as I later found out my surgeon is considered one of the best (even pioneered new techniques). In my case I think there was only 7-10 days difference in timing between the two choices. I received my diagnosis on December 15 and my surgery was on January 25. My cancer had spread to my lymph nodes, but I doubt it happened quickly as I had extranodal extension on both nodes biopsied and my oncologist felt I had extensive lymph node involvement.

Posts.Title: Am I a drama queen? Sunflowersandweeds Sunflowersandweeds

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2012 01:43PM Lou10 wrote: Lots of abnormalities classified as BIRADS 4 are not malignant. The range is huge, starting at only 2% (see below and note that "wide range of probability" does not mean high probability!) Try to focus on the positive part of your report: suggestive of benign mass.  It's good you're getting it biopsied to make sure. Hoping for the best for you. BI-RADS 4 Suspicious Abnormality - Biopsy Should Be Considered: BI-RADS 4 is reserved for findings that do not have the classic appearance of malignancy but have a wide range of probability of malignancy (2 - 95%).
Posts.Title: What is "heterogeneously dense" mean Shellbell431 Mbran

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2011 09:41AM Lou10 wrote: Are you on an antibiotic? That's what did me in. As for Ketorolac, I asked my surgeon if I could use that after surgery as I already had some from previous mouth surgery. She didn't want me to use it because of possible bleeding, but every surgeon has their preferences, and maybe it was something about my "constitution". I remember from taking it before that the instruction was not to take it for longer than 5 days, but it was fine to stop it earlier. This may not apply to your situation so better to ask.... I hope you've now got it sorted out.
Posts.Title: Anyone taken Ketorolac? TMI! BioAdoptMom3 Lou10

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2011 10:05AM Lou10 wrote: MariaEP, I'm glad your doc is being thorough. My breast was sore intermittently and had increased in size ... And because I have very dense breasts (>75%), my primary tumour did not show up on either mammogram or ultrasound until after I discovered a hardened area and a "dent" in my breast. Even when I was diagnosed with cancer after a core biopsy, the mammogram and ultrasound images of the tumour weren't very clear, so the surgeon ordered an MRI. The MRI clearly showed the malignancy plus a SECOND malignancy that had been completely missed. (And now, after almost a year of cancer treatment and a fairly high risk of recurrence, it seems I may have a fight on my hands to get an MRI as part of my follow up. Go figure.) No one ever told me that the degree of density of my breasts was among the strongest risk factors for breast cancer, in addition to making it much harder to detect. I stumbled upon the risk information on a section of the Cancer Agency's website for health professional. Wasn't even told this before surgery ... had I been, I think I would at least have considered other surgical options. So ... if breast density is an issue for you, you may want to talk to your doc about whether an MRI would be warranted, regardless of the results of the biopsy. I sure hope your lump is benign and your fears are put to rest.
Posts.Title: Mammogram and ultrasound negative MariaEP Tenmom

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2012 05:17PM Lou10 wrote: When I go to different places for breast scans -- mammogram, ultrasound or MRI -- I have copies on hand of previous breast scans at other facilities, as sometimes information-sharing doesn't work as well as it should.  Wherever you have your MRI, it probably won't be as bad as you expect.
Posts.Title: Question about breast MRIs benny4663 benny4663

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2012 09:00PM Lou10 wrote: The breast surgeon may review the pathology report from your biopsy as well as your risk factors, and discuss preventive options. Perhaps surgical excision of the tissue is an option.  Do you have a copy of your biopsy report yet?  Here's a link to a page from Johns Hopkins on Atypical Hyperplasia -- Understanding Your Pathology Report, in case it might be helpful.  http://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/avon_foundation_breast_center/treatments_services/breast_cancer_diagnosis/breast_pathology/atypical_hyperplasia_faq.html
Posts.Title: Why a Breast Surgeon? erinm216 CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2012 01:08PM Lou10 wrote: Different hospitals/agencies have slightly different MRI machines and procedures. Do you know where you'll have yours? The Cancer Agency? My pre-surgery MRI had two parts, one in which I was lying on my back and another in which I was lying facedown. I was extremely anxious as it was my first MRI too. I took Ativan beforehand. Also I made sure not to look at the tube when I entered the room or when they were repositioning me ... kept my eyes closed whenever possible. The tube is open at both ends and you have a "call" button in your hand. The noise can be deafening, particularly with the older machines, but I actually found it helped distract me.  If your MRI has been scheduled, or you at least know where it will be, you could call the MRI department and ask questions about the procedure. Maybe ask first if there's someone who can talk to you about it, in case the person who answers the phone is busy. Great that you're having the MRI. My pre-surgery MRI found a second cancer (missed by digital mammogram and ultrasound), so afterwards I was very glad the surgeon had ordered one!
Posts.Title: Question about breast MRIs benny4663 benny4663

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2012 02:37PM Lou10 wrote: Yes, my pre-surgery breast MRI was done at the Cancer Agency. I've had two follow-up breast MRIs at Lion's Gate (newer equipment). Also had brain and neck MRIs at St. Paul's, so I've been around!
Posts.Title: Question about breast MRIs benny4663 benny4663

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2012 04:44PM - edited Sep 23, 2012 04:49PM by Lou10 I like Lion's Gate Hospital because of the newer equipment and the environment. Apparently LGH has excellent breast imaging software. My follow-up breast MRIs at LGH were face down only and my body went into the tube first, not my head (which I find easier). Also I could see out the bottom. Last time they asked if I wanted music and put on a radio station for me ... hadn't had that before. I actually didn't like it as I couldn't hear it that well any way over the noise of the machine and it was almost too much stimulation. I think I'd ask for no music next time but that's just me.
